captions.text:
There is one phrase that
I have always wanted
to say to everyone in my life.
That phrase is "Life is easy."
It's so easy and fun.
I never thought like that before.

When I was in Bangkok, I felt like
life is very hard, very complicated.

I was born in a poor village
on the Northeastern of Thailand

And when I was a kid,
everything was fun and easy,

but when the TV came,
many people came to the village,
they said,

"You are poor, you need to chase
success in your life.

You need to go to Bangkok
to pursue success in your life."
So I felt bad, I felt poor.
So I needed to go to Bangkok.

When I went to Bangkok,
it was not very fun.

You need to learn, study
a lot and work very hard,
and then you can get success.

I worked very hard,
eight hours per day at least,

but all I could eat was just
a bowl of noodles per meal,

or some Tama dish
of fried rice or something like that.

And where I stayed was very bad,
a small room where a lot of people slept.
It was very hot.
I started to question a lot.
When I work hard, why is my life so hard?
It must be something wrong,

because I produce a lot of things,
but I cannot get enough.
And I tried to learn, I tried to study.
I tried to study in the university.

It's very hard to learn in university,
because it's very boring.
(Laughter)

And when I looked at subjects
in the university,

in every faculty, most of them
had destructive knowledge.

There's no productive knowledge
in university for me.

If you learn to be
an architect or engineer,
that means you ruin more.

The more these people work,
the mountain will be destroyed more.
And a good land in Chao Praya Basin

will be covered
with concrete more and more.
We destroy more.

If we go to agriculture faculty
or something like that,
that means we learn how to poison,
to poison the land, the water,
and learn to destroy everything.

I feel like everything we do
is so complicated, so hard.
We just make everything hard.

Life was so hard
and I felt disappointed.

I started to think about,
why did I have to be in Bangkok?
I thought about when I was a kid,
nobody worked eight hours per day,

everybody worked two hours,
two months a year,

planting rice one month
and harvesting the rice another month.

The rest is free time,
ten months of free time.

That's why people have
so many festivals in Thailand,
every month they have festival.
(Laughter)
Because they have so much free time.

And then in the daytime,
everyone even takes a nap.
Even now in Laos, go to Laos if you can,
people take a nap after lunch.
And after they wake up, they just gossip,

how's your son-in-law,
how's your wife, daughter-in-law.
People have a lot of time,
but because they have a lot of time,
they have time to be with themselves.

And when they have time
to be with themselves,
they have time to understand themselves.
When they understand themselves,
they can see what they want in their life.

So, many people see
that they want happiness,

they want love,
they want to enjoy their life.

So, people see
a lot of beauty in their life,
so they express that beauty in many ways.

Some people by carving
the handle of their knife,
very beautiful,
they weave the baskets very nicely.
But, now, nobody does that.
Nobody can do something like that.
People use plastic everywhere.

So, I feel like
it's something wrong in there,
I cannot live this way I'm living.
So, I decided to quit University,
and went back home.

When I went back home,
I started to live like I remember,
like when I was a kid.
I started to work two months a year.
I got four tons of rice.
And the whole family, six people,
we eat less than half a ton per year.
So we can sell some rice.
I took two ponds, two fish ponds.
We have fish to eat all year round.
And I started a small garden.
Less than half an acre.

And I spend 15 minutes per day
to take care of the garden.

I have more than 30 varieties
of vegetables in the garden.
So, six people cannot eat all of it.
We have a surplus to sell in the market.
We can make some income, too.

So, I feel like, it's easy,
why did I have to be in Bangkok

for seven years, working hard
and then not have enough to eat,

but here, only two months a year
and 15 minutes per day
I can feed six people.
That's easy.

And before I thought
that stupid people like me
who never got a good grade at school,
cannot have a house.
Because people who are cleverer than me,

who are number one
in the class every year,
they get a good job,

but they need to work more
than 30 years to have a house.

But me, who cannot finish university,
how could I have a house?

Hopeless for people
who have low education, like me.

But, then I started to do
earthly building, it's so easy.

I spend two hours per day,
from 5 o'clock in the morning,

until 7 o'clock in the morning,
two hours per day.
And in three months, I got a house.

And another friend
who's the most clever in the class,

he spent three months
to build his house, too.

But, he had to be in debt.
He had to pay for his debt for 30 years.

So, compared to him, I have
29 years and 10 months of free time.
(Laughter)
So, I feel that life is so easy.

I never thought I could
build a house as easy as that.

And I keep building a house every year,
at least one house every year.

Now, I have no money,
but I have many houses.
(Laughter)

My problem is in which house
I will sleep tonight.
(Laughter)

So, a house is not a problem,
anybody can build a house.
The kids, 13 years old, at the school,

they make bricks together,
they make a house.
After one month, they have a library.
The kids can make a house,

a very old nun can build
a hut for herself.
Many people can build a house.
So, it's easy.
If you don't believe me, try it.
If somebody wants to have a house.
And then, the next thing is clothing.

I felt like I'm poor,
like I'm not handsome.

I tried to dress like somebody else,
like a movie star.
To make myself look good, look better.

I spent one month to save money
to buy a pair of jeans.

When I wore them,
I turned left, I turned right,
looked in the mirror.
Every time I look, I am the same person.

The most expensive pants
cannot change my life.

I felt like I'm so crazy,
why did I have to buy them?
Spend one month to have a pair of pants.
It doesn't change me.
I started to think more about that.
Why do we need to follow fashion?

Because, when we follow fashion,
we never catch up with it,
because we follow it.
So, don't follow it, just stay here.
(Laughter)
Use what you have.

So, after that, until now, 20 years,
I have never bought any clothes.

All the clothes I have
are leftovers from people.

When people come to visit me,
and when they leave,
they leave a lot of clothes there.
So, I have tons of clothes now.
(Laughter)

And when people see me
wear very old clothes,
they give me more clothes.
(Laughter)

So, my problem is, I need
to give clothes to people very often.
(Laughter)
So, it's so easy.

And when I stopped buying clothes,
I felt like, it's not only clothes,
it's about something else in my life,

What I learned is that
when I buy something,

and I think about,
I buy it because I like it,
or I buy it because I need it.

So, if I buy it because I like it,
that means I'm wrong.

So, I feel more free
when I think like this.

And the last thing is,
when I get sick, what will I do?

I really worried in the beginning,
because then I had no money.
But, I started to contemplate more.

Normally, sickness is a normal thing,
it's not a bad thing.

Sickness is something to remind us
that we did something wrong in our lives,
that's why we got sick.

So, when I get sick, I need
to stop and come back to myself.
And think about it, what I did was wrong.

So, I learned how to use
water to heal myself,
how to use earth to heal myself,

I learned how to use
basic knowledge to heal myself.

So, now that I rely on myself
in these four things,
I feel like life is very easy,

I feel something
like freedom, I feel free.

I feel like I don't worry
about anything much,

I have less fear, I can do
whatever I want in my life.

Before, I had a lot of fear,
I could not do anything.

But, now I feel very free,
like I'm a unique person on this Earth,

nobody like me, I don't need
to make myself like anybody else.
I'm the number one.

So, things like this
make it easy, very light.

And, after that,
I started to think about

that when I was in Bangkok,
I felt very dark in my life.

I started to think that many people
maybe thought like me at the time.

So, we started a place called
"Pun Pun" in Chiang Mai.
The main aim is just saving seed.

To collect seed,
because seed is food, food is life.
If there is no seed, no life.
No seed, no freedom.
No seed, no happiness.

Because your life
depends on somebody else.
Because you have no food.
So, it's very important to save seed.
That's why we focus on saving seed.
That's the main thing in Pun Pun.

And the second thing
is it is the learning center.

We want to have a center
for ourselves to learn,
learn how to make life easy.

Because we were taught to make
life complicated and hard all the time.
How can we make it easy? It's easy,

but we don't know
how to make it easy anymore.
Because we always make it complicated

and now, we start to learn,
and learn to be together.

Because, we were taught
to disconnect ourselves
from everything else, to be independent,
so we can rely on the money only.
We don't need to rely on each other.

But now, to be happy,
we need to come back,

to connect to ourselves again,
to connect to other people,

to connect our mind and body
together again.
So, we can be happy. Life is easy.

And from beginning until now,
what I learned

is the four basic needs:
food, house, clothes and medicine
must be cheap and easy for everybody,
that's the civilization.

But, if you make these four things hard
and very hard for many people to get,
that's uncivilized.

So, now when we look
at everywhere around us,
everything is so hard to get.

I feel like now is the most
uncivilized era of humans on this Earth.

We have so many people
who finish university,
have so many universities on the Earth,
have so many clever people on this Earth.
But, life is harder and harder.
We make it hard for whom?
We work hard for whom right now?
I feel like it's wrong, it's not normal.
So, I just want to come back to normal.

To be a normal person,
to be equal to animals.
The birds make a nest in one or two days.
The rats dig a hole in one night.
But, the clever humans like us
spend 30 years to have a house,

and many people can't believe
that they can have a house in this life.
So, that's wrong.

Why do we destroy our strength,
why do we destroy our ability that much?

So, I feel that it's enough for me,
to live in the normal way,
in the abnormal way.
So, now I try to be normal.

But, people look at me
as the abnormal one.
(Laughter)
A crazy person.

But, I don't care,
because it's not my fault.
It's their fault, they think like that.
So, my life is easy and light now.
That's enough for me.
People can think whatever they want.
I cannot manage anything outside myself.

What I can do is change my mind,
manage my mind.

Now, my mind is light
and easy, that's enough.

If anybody wants to have a choice,
you can have a choice.

The choice to be easy or to be hard,
it depends on you.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Life is easy. Why do we make it so hard? | Jon Jandai | TEDxDoiSuthep

He is talking about progressivism. If we stopped and just used and 
appreciated what we have now, it'd be much more simple. We fail because we

have and live in the moment. ﻿
comments.author: Benn Leyland

comments.text:
The Dalai Lama, when asked what surprised him most about humanity, answered 
"Man.... Because he sacrifices his health in order to make money. Then he 
sacrifices money to recuperate his health. And then he is so anxious about 
the future that he does not enjoy the present; the result being that he 
does not live in the present or the future; he lives as if he is never 
going to die, and then dies having never really lived." That is all I will 
say.﻿

comments.text:
His ideas sound wonderful but it just can't be. How is an old, arthritic, 
one handed woman like me supposed to build her own house? How do surgeons 
get trained? How does water get distributed to everyone? How do we power 
light, heat, refrigeration, equipment? What it all boils down to is that in 
order to be happy (at least as happy as you CAN be on earth) we have to 
have a relationship with God. Now I'm not a 'holy boly' person but I've 
lived life for 'getting ahead' and I've lived it for getting to know God. 
There is no replacement for God, it has to be HIM. All happiness, 
contentment, joy, peace, love, life, hope, breath...comes from Him! I've 
lived it, I know. Live your life for God and He will see that all is well. 
People say 'Oh ya? Well if that's true then why does my son have cancer?' 
and things like that. God provides ALL you need if you remain with Him, 
that doesn't mean everything will go your way, it means you will never go 
through hardships alone and you will be given the strength and hope to get 
through it and come out the other side stronger for it and closer to God. 
Happiness isn't living life simple, it's living it with God. God is what 
makes it simple. Because if you strive to be closer with God every day, HE 
becomes what you need, nothing of this world is needed. Trust me, I've 
lived it.﻿

making the right choice.

comments.text:
+Begench Turayev I don't know how far your knowledge of Chinese society 
actually extends but permit me to say, as an expat who interacts with young 
Chinese citizens daily, that life in China is not easy. Despite the fact 
that they can now feed more people there is still a huge number of those 
1.something billions who is still struggling for a bowl of rice. University 
students study their butts off every single day and all most of them have 
to look forward to is a low paying entry level job from which they will 
most likely not be able to progress.

Yes, technology and science have given us ways to feed more people 
(emphasis on "more") but it obviously is not enough to reach everyone. We 
can't all expect to live in the same lifestyle nor can we expect everyone 
to follow the same path. That is probably not mathematically even possible. 
Can everyone be a manager? A doctor? A lawyer? A CEO? A rockstar?


My takeaway from this person's talk is that there needs to be more than one 
path for people to follow towards a happy and healthy life. I agree with 
you that life is complicated but we make it needlessly hard by pushing 
ourselves and others to doing the same darn thing everyone else is doing. 
If your takeaway has been that he is trying to sell a book and buy a richer 
lifestyle, that's your prerogative and I respect that. I think, though, 
that it is foolish to believe that anyone - aside from people like Stephen 
King - can turn their life around by just simply selling a few thousand 
copies of a book.

comments.text:
+pjamesbda do you mind defining violent oppression? I tend to believe that 
the private sector (assuming strong property rights) is less violent than 
the damage government has done like wars, oppression of its people and 
creating gross inequality. I know about Milton Freidman but I don't fully 
know his position. Idisagree with his monetary policy. In a free market the 
ones who are the most productive may be the successful but it doesn't come 
at a cost to other people. It actually does the opposite. Why I say this is 
because with more production comes cheaper prices. The wages for people 
working for a low wage can buy more and life is less costly. A capitalistic 
economy rewards people who provide goods that are demanded by people to 
improve their life. A capitalistic economy encourages production of the 
goods demanded in the most efficient manner because of the price system 
that cannot be replicated in other systems. Unless you can replace market 
prices without a market, capitalism is a great system. Know that without 
government stifling competition corporations have to be valuable to its 
customers or else they will leave. Customers have the power by voting with 
their wallet. Morally, free market capitalism has liberty and property 
rights unequalled as compared to socialism which ignores private property. 
Their is more freedom and the working class benefits too.

dichotomy. Or rather a reaction against it (a product of it?). Fact is, if 
land owners only needed to work 2 hours a day to feed their immediate 
family members, that means they were not contributing  to any larger 
causes. Like paying percentage of income to larger, more organized groups 
who could think, plan and act further into the future. Who would have said 
that such landholdings were being "under utilized". This was the logic at 
work I think, and how terrain was settled in the past, by merging and 
combing interests and wealth, to form central powers. Either by force, or 
by persuasion. Otherwise there would only be chains of self-interested 
small holders, that would run into problems when disaster strikes. Another 
older word for this is of course called paying tribute (if not paying for 
protection), especially because it would have involved giving up amounts of 
personal independence and wealth to something larger. That's where the 
brain versus brawn dichotomy comes in doesn't it? How to persuade other to 
give up more of themselves, to be part of something larger than themselves?﻿

comments.text:
I usually don't write youtube comments, especially a comment of this 
length, but I really find this video interesting. This is a beautiful way 
to view the world, but unfortunately due to the massive growth in 
population because of technology, artificial food production, etc, the 
world population is just too large for all of us to live this way. We all 
make up one larger organism, and if you increase the availability and 
amount of food, the survivability and health, and the means of 
transportation to a ever-growing organism then it will continue to grow. 
For me personally, that is where the real challenge arises. The challenge 
is that you must take the principles Jon discusses here and live by them in 
our modernized world. Why? Because there are many people out there that are 
born into poverty in a system that does not allow them to go off and live a 
natural life but rather continue to struggle in the system to barely 
survive. Where is a person of poverty going to move in New York to grow 
their own rice and build their own home? If we all begin to live and think 
like Jon though, we could begin by making smaller changes. Maybe that means 
simply buying food from local organic sources, or instead of buying the 
latest gadget or new car you can use that money to make sure that a person 
has a meal to eat. Instead of using your free time to endlessly surf the 
web, dedicate some of that time to volunteer to local co-ops of any sort, 
or play a more active role in local politics. Again I agree with what Jon 
says here, but it just is not realistic for us to all just move to the 
mountains and live a natural life so we must do our part within the system. 
Hopefully in time the world will evolve to represent some of the ideals Jon 
speaks of here.﻿

comments.text:
13:11 "We have so many cleaver people on this earth, but life is just 
harder and harder. We make it hard for who? We work hard for who? I feel 
like it's wrong"

His questioning is actually related to capitalism itself. Capitalism is a 
very good system in the sense that it gives every person a chance to 
improve, regardless of who they are, as well as providing people with the 
freedom to chose the way they want to live. However, we pay a very high 
price to maintain it: this system naturally generates huge social 
inequality, which means that the enormous wealth of very few people is kept 
by the hard work of billions of people, structured in a very complex and 
gigant hierarchical network of job division across the planet. 

Now, don't get me wrong. I fully support a system that rewards the ones who 
work harder. But capitalism as it is today is a complete joke: While people 
struggle to have a decent life in the poorest parts of the world, suffering 
from every kind of disease from anything they eat or any water they drink, 
multimillionaries struggle to make their first billion dollars, negotiating 
shares of stockmarkets, and making private investments in various bussiness 
across the planet just for the sake of watching the numbers on their bank 
account grow, as if it was a game. But it's not. It's mathematics: the 
world has a limited amount of money, and if someone makes more, it's 
actually taking away from someone else, in this case, from the ones who 
needed it the most, to the ones that didn't need it at all. ﻿

with greater expectations of yourself. You know who you are, so you know 
what to expect for yourself in the long run, if you are capable of 
perceiving life that way. Life is hard, but it is your willingness to 
accept that challenge that makes it "less hard", because of you interests 
and goals. For example, do you think that it is easy for a drug addict to 
step in rehab and reform his personality from what he is so used to being 
or accepting as "great"? Clearly, for that person, life is not great and 
needs a change. And with that change, comes hard work and commitment. Those 
are not easy factors to ultimate success. 

Does a prisoner, who was wrongly accused of committing a horrendous crime 
and now must face extensive jail time, go through life thinking "this is 
going to be easy", or "this is how it was meant to be and now I have no 
control of it"? Or is that person going to do whatever it takes and go 
through all of that HARD work to prove innocence and achieve freedom once 
again? Think about that..

comments.text:
. . . Jon Jandai was a happy child in the countryside of Thailand. He 
followed advice to go to the big city and get a good education. He found 
the academic work ethic there put him on a path where he worked hard in a 
non-sensical world for crazy goals, and little returns. He lived in squalor 
and discomfort trying to achieve the standard goals of the society. The 
best achievers there learned how to "pave paradise and put up a parking 
lot" (Joni Mitchell). Eventually he decided to return home and live a 
simple life which we have heard before from John Denver in the song: Thank 
God I'm a Country Boy. Those who did better than Jon in the urban school 
built a house in 3 months, like he did in the country, but his former 
classmate (the supposedly smarter city kid with a good education) had to 
assume a 30 year mortgage. Because he did not have to do this, he figures 
he gained 29 years and 10 months extra time to enjoy living. Jon Jandai 
says that people have 4 basic needs: food, shelter, clothing, and health, 
and to obtain them you do NOT need to sacrifice and work so hard. He says 
it is possible to live a life of ease and leisure and work very little. He 
says the modern, industrial mindset has made for the most crazy and 
inhumane working and living conditions. He says he has not purchased 
clothing for 20 years, and yet he is given too much clothing all the time, 
so he has to give it away himself. All of this Henry David Thoreau type of: 
Simplify, Simplify, Simplify talk is also reminiscent of Jesus's sayings in 
the Sermon on the Mount: Behold the birds of the air: for they sow not, 
neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father 
feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they? Consider the lilies of the 
field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin: And yet I say 
unto you, That even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of 
these. Matthew 6:26~30. He declares that a bird or natural animal builds 
it's home or nest in a day or two. Human beings think they are so smart, 
but they get in debt for 30 years to build their nests. He implies this is 
not superior intelligence: it is crazy and stupid. All of this back to 
nature, simple, sensible country life advice is given by an appealing 
country gentleman with sincerity, charm, and a quiet, persuasive urgency to 
modern mankind to save our lives from the hellish, non-sensical, endless 
treadmills, human hamster wheels, and idiotic sacrifice of the conventional 
urban lifestyles of the uber-smart, upwardly mobile people we all admire to 
our great detriment. He urges that sacrificing health and most of lifetime 
for relentless pursuit of money has left people impoverished. He says we 
live in the most inhumane times because of that. He exemplifies and urges a 
return to a gentle, rural, agricultural lifestyle, and renewal of sensible, 
normal human connection with family, friends, and neighbors.﻿
comments.author: Richard Curry

comments.text:
Thank you, Ric. Nice one-I hadn't meant that you move to Thailand, lol. I

comments.author: Bill Rawthee

comments.text:
+Bill Rawthee One comment from someone else: You know you don't have to 
completely disconnect to take some aspects of what he says into your life, 
right? Mr. Jandai has a pattern of life for himself in which he is number 1 
in the world. We each make accommodations for specifically ourselves. If 
your question asks have I dropped anything and moved to the countryside of 
Thailand, my answer is no. I have never been to Southeast Asia. But his 
message is so simple and universal, and actually so obvious and common 
sensical, that it is a refreshing reality check for all of us, where ever 
we are, whatever we are doing. Making things over-complicated and 
unnecessarily difficult is a pervasive malady for all mankind. I am, to the 
best of my ability, practicing simplicity and efficiency whenever and where 
ever possible. It is a journey. It is not perhaps an ultimate and final 
attainment that can be crossed off a to-do list. But thank you for asking, 
Bill Rawthee, whom I would not know from Adam. Are you practicing this, 
Bill Rawthee?

True, so for the time being we must exist in this monster of a system we 
have created but at the same time embrace his message and look for ways to 
move toward a more simple life and inspire other's to do the same.

Sure it's extremely hard to jump into this lifestyle full swing in a 
developed country with all kinds of rules, regulations, and limitations but 
we can limit our overindulgence in simple ways and continue to move forward 
from there.

We don't need a TV in every room (or a tv at all) we don't need a 3 bedroom 
house as a childless couple, we don't need to go out to eat all the time, 
we don't need to spend so much money on clothes, etc. There are many ways 
in which we can slowly move toward the way of life he's suggesting and as 
we all embrace this message instead of just accepting the system we have 
maybe the system will slowly begin to change, after all it is of our own 
fabrication, it isn't a living entity in itself.

Exactly. It's not so easy, and basically impossible, for those of us who 
live in 1st world countries. Where I am in Canada, you need permits for 
everything. You own nothing, not even the land or house you bought. If I 
want to build an extra bedroom on my house I need permission from someone 
else. If I was to hang a clothesline, I need permission. If I want to chop 
down a tree, I need permission. We can't grow much here; the growing season 
is about 3 months here and we barely get enough sun. If a Canadian wanted 
an easy life they would need to leave Canada, and their family and friends, 
behind making it not-so-easy. In that way I envy people like this man for 
having the option to live the easy life.

comments.text:
+danpt2000 Well, that is easier said than done. In most Western countries 
such a life style would effectively isolate you. If you have children they 
would be bullied and perhaps develop a range of mental problems. Also, you 
would have to have a lot of money to make the transition. Buying land and 
building equipment is not for free. Also, you can't just build a house 
yourself. In Western countries everything is regulated. You need permits 
and unless you are an engineer you need professionals to design, plan and 
supervise your building project. Also, if everyone moved to the countryside 
and lived of their own crops we would have no doctors, nurses and other 
health professionals. We would have no police to protect us. We would have 
no fire department. Progress would effectively come to a halt. No new 
medicines and no new surgical procedures. No more knowledge about how the 
world works. No internet and no other modern communications. No cars, no 
ships, no airplanes. We would be living like they did centuries ago, and 
life wasn't all rosy back then. People died of easily preventable diseases. 
If the crops failed people starved to death. People succumbed to natural 
disasters. There were also wars back then. In many ways what he is 
promoting is the law of the jungle. With all it's flaws, the modern world 
is the most peaceful ever.
comments.author: Probus Excogitatoris

comments.text:
Well, what he forgets to mention is that when he gets sick there will be no 
hospital around. Everyone can't build a hospital, everyone can't produce 
medicine or perform surgery. These are skills for which you need education 
and technology. We need technology and education. But, I agree that we 
spend so much resources and time on things that really does not bring us 
happiness or even contribute to our well-being. In many ways we are truly 
slaves. You often hear that we don't have enough money to feed the poor, 
etc. That is complete bullshit. Trillions of dollars have been spent on the 
Iraqi and Afghanistan wars. That is not billions but trillions of dollars. 
Imagine what we could do with that money. Then think about how much food 
and other stuff we just throw away here in the Western world. How much 
energy and resources we spend on stuff that really has no real purpose or 
does not contribute to our well-being. We work around the clock to be able 
to afford things that we don't need and don't make us happy. At the same 
time scientists are struggling to find funding for important project like 
curing disease. If someone asked us to donate hundred dollars a month to 
cancer research, most people would say no. But, the same people would 
gladly spend hundreds of dollars a month on designer clothes and luxury 
food. It's madness. We are consuming ourselves to death. We spend our time 
and resources on things that are ultimately pointless, while we ignore the 
areas of life that are crucial. Humans are so stupid.
comments.author: Probus Excogitatoris

ago, and I did it for non-spiritual reasons, but there is something about 
the increase of consciousness that makes you aware that there is more to 
life than the mere physical, and there is more than your mind. You become 
aware of your very perception. Its like being aware that you are watching 
your life happen through a cinema screen, and you control the movie, except 
that you don't know where the place is that you control it from. And you 
can increase the resolution of the movie by meditating, and the effect is 
immediate. The more I have meditated, the more I realize that the world can 
be perfect If we only choose to see it that way. And being in this state is 
complete bliss, because nothing can ever be perceived as wrong - life can 
only be seen as a fun game, and the so called 'evil' is merely a challenge 
to overcome in order to improve. And the funnest part of the game is 
figuring out what the game is all about - analyzing the way the mechanics 
work and how best to improve your control over your own character. Meditate 
deep enough and you might even learn cheat codes, like supernatural 
healing. Before I meditated, I thought that healing could be done, but only 
by special people with lots of experience. But now I see that anyone can do 
it, as long as they have faith. I can understand why people get scared away 
from the idea of spiritual meditation, but in the end you dont have to do 
it for spiritual reasons - but you will probably end up being spiritual 
because of it,

comments.text:
I agree many things are made unnecessarily complicate in the modern world 
but I still would not go to the another extreme, to stop all development.

Modern society isn't inefficient but the fact is that people set their 
living standards all the time higher and higher. Another problem is that 
money has too much power in certain decisions. In capitalism, it's a bad 
business to make a very good product because people would buy that kind of 
product only once. Instead there is many forces that cause products to age, 
like the only purpose of fashion is to make your old car or clothes look 
crap and make you to buy a new item. Or house that isn't built to last. For 
example a wooden house, technically can stand 500 years. Still normal 
peoples houses nowadays are build with so low quality that they must be 
rebuilt every 50 years. Indeed does great for economy and peoples jobs but 
very much explains why we have to be all the time working.

But should still understand that if everyone lived like the man in this 
video, we would not have: modern healthcare, internet, comfortable homes 
that are easy to live in, easy jobs in the office, as most hard manual work 
is now done by machines. Instead we might have a lot of free time. But 
because people are naturally active, they want to do something with their 
free time. And in western countries it has went to that many people use 
their free time to increase their living standards.

Reason why houses are expensive in western countries is more that the 
property is expensive and there is very heavy bureaucracy in the building 
regulations, and third of course the law of capitalism here again demand, 
everyone want a house which forces the prices to increase. My grand parents 
and their ancestors mostly built their houses by themselves. Although here 
in the north it doesn't happen as easily as in the video, because it's -40 
C in the winter, you need a good house. They were also farmers but to my 
understanding life is much easier now than then. Then all work was done 
manually that can now be done by machines.

comments.text:
I got my degree in design & architecture. The built environment is 
artificial. You must destroy to get those materials for construction and 
afterwards, much of it goes to waste. The process of engineering and 
architecture is inherently destructive. You can try to minimise waste but 
the destruction happens. Jon is more right than you know. He can say that 
because he IS an architect. He's built 10 houses already from mud bricks, 
clay and other easily recyclables from the land. What he uses he can regrow 
and/or repurpose. When he talks about architecture, he's coming at it from 
the point of view as an architect and a builder. In its modern incarnation, 
architecture is destructive. That isn't to say ALL architecture is 
destructive. Some more forward thinking architects/engineers are thinking 
about designing with sustainability in mind, building with natural, 
renewable, reusable materials. The vast majority of architects & 
architecture, however, is about destruction in order to suit modern 
requirements, which is itself destructive.

Witch Crescini.  Fundamental of his thought and actions are based of 
Budhism, if let alone nirvana which is spiritual, living in harmony with 
nature and awareness of how our existence interrelate with nature is one of 
the keys. I too, a trained engineer, had worked successfully in the 
industry for over 20 years.
Generally, in engineer's world, we quantify things to justify things... Jon 
Jandai's talk was surrounding things that we normally not quantify... " 
happiness in life ". Sometime it is simply a trend, changed and adaptted 
through human's history. His " Happiness in life " is back to basic human 
being needs + living in harmony with nature and the community he lives in...

Let's see if you agree with me.
Scientists / Chemists create materials like cement / metal etc...
We, engineer make use of those to build buildings / roads / tunnel  etc... 
to solve mankind problems WE CREATED... eg, Human WANT to transposrt things 
to a faraway places, WANT high rise building to serve highly populated 
city... etc. etc..
And it's justified because we consider those with the equation : needs + 
economic impact - environmental impact > 0
and we been doing that for a long long time, long enough to make it our 
paradigm which hard to be shifted.... Just a very basic example.... We pour 
concrete on an acre of fetile soil to make road or build an office 
building... it was easily justifed because back when we start doing this, 
fertile land was abundant.... it's become critical now, with all the mono 
crop and synthetic fertilizer...our soil now become bare dirt.  what about 
next 50-100 years ??  If we fair to the world, we, engineer would have 
say... S_it, we have been screwing ourself for the past 150 years... 

Now, a big movment in USA is back to homestead and permaculture which is 
what Jon Jandai has been practicing for decades.

I always tried to understand why the game minecraft is so succesful and why 
i enjoy it so much because its such a easy game. Now i know why: Because it 
represents the easy way of life. You get the stuff you really need and 
build your house and make your own food. NO EXPENSIVE CAR, NO MONEY...etc. 
And i always felt more complete and happy if i played the game. And now i 
know why. I miss the easy life. I only work for things that i dont need or 
could build by my own. Yes i cant build a house like people who learned 
this and it wouldnt be that good. But why do i need a better one? To 
impress some people! But a selfmade house is impressive too because i build 
it with my own hands, isnt it? So why do i have to work years to impress 
people with my house if i can build it by my own in a few months? Its still 
impressive because i did this and not someone i paid for.﻿

comments.text:
A lifestyle like tis requires a structure to support it. That is not to say 
it needs to be a large, complicated structure, but a market is necessary 
for people to sell their food (probably operating off of barter), and there 
needs to be a place for sick people who can't be treated with the remedies 
he prescribed (unless you want to let them die), and what if they have a 
bad winter and the rice dies (I don't know how rice works, but you get the 
idea).

The systems we see like government, the global economy, and the medical 
system have been created with two ideas in mind. There is the desire to 
help and support, and there is the desire to acquire power and money. You 
can view them as opposites.

He is making a very good point. We need to reconsider how we tend to add 
things to our lives instead of only deal with what we need. I advocate this 
but I don't think it will work for all people in society. 

Doctors and surgeons, for example, don't have much choice when it comes to 
stress. By nature, their job requires them to know many people, to remember 
them, to deal with lots of stress when a person needs to be treated or a 
heart needs to be operated on.

If we are to live in a society where it is dumbed down, we will have to 
 identify and fight the free that is often the motivator in expansion and 
addition.﻿

I'm already 38 and I am nowhere. I don't know if I can retire by 65!

Now, for the first time in my life, I truly have a dream. I want this. I 
don't want to retire anymore. I have plans to work doubly hard to pay off 
what I owe. And when I am done, I will drop all of it and do this. I will 
have enough to eat, to wear, a place to live, time to spare, people to talk 
to. I want to stop struggling.

For those who can't see how to do this, it's easy. Finish up on what you 
owe in this society because there is no running away. But when you're done, 
have enough to travel to a few of these places to un-learn everything. This 
requires you to never turn back.﻿

comments.text:
I don't know about Thailand but after watching this video I went to my 
grandma and asked her to tell me about her everyday family life in her 
childhood and also how it looked like in the times of her parents and 
grandparents. I didn't tell about this video, I just asked. Their 
occupation was farming and taking care of their livestock. In my country, 
even in the 50's most rural houses still didn't have electricity. They had 
much less free time that we do now and they had to work hard, physically, 
much of the day, maybe apart from winter time since they had stored food 
and livestock ready to be killed. It wasn't also that rare for people to go 
hungry or die from typhoid or influenca. Infant mortality rate was also 
high compared to nowadays. I think what Jon describes is idealized. Maybe 
he can do it since other people bring him stuff.﻿

comments.text:
I believe a lot of people are missing the point so here's my five cents:
His reference to building ones own house, working less, making ones own 
medicine etc. don't have literal meanings esp. to someone living in a 
developed country. You have to be open-minded and formulate what you deem 
sensible from what he's saying. To me, he's saying establish your own 
ground rules. If you think working 8 hrs is a need, and is ''easy'' for 
you, then do it! If you think being fashion-forward makes your life easy 
and acceptable, then go by all means go for it! However, (now this is a 
major point), in comparison to the life he leads, and in his opinion, it's 
much simpler when he does things the way he does. If you think living like 
his friend who took 30 years to own a years is desirable, then go for it! I 
entirely understand that from a 1st world POV, it sounds ridiculous to live 
his life. Nonetheless, do whatever you think makes your life easier. ﻿

such as Gabor Mate, Robert Sapolsky, James Gillian or Richard Wilkinson

comments.text:
+Herman Pienaar Listen carefully, and try to understand your peer, for he 
is not contradicting what you are saying. What I understand from him is 
that TODAY, even if you don´t like it or disagree with it, land is owned by 
someone by law. That is not to say we approve or disagree, or that is bad 
or good: it is what it is. So I agree that is questionable  to carry on 
practicing the concept of ownership if we want a healthy society, but that 
doesnt mean that private property does not exist (I wish it didn´t though) 
and that we should all take a piece of the earth for ourselves. We are 7 
billion people, I don´t think that an exponential system such as 
demographics its sustainable in time in a relation of 1 house-1 individual, 
let alone 7 houses 1 individual. Why he needs so many houses, when there 
are millions of homeless people?. I dont recall him saying he built those 
houses for somebody else. Im not saying that some people should not have a 
home because there is no room, on the contrary I´ m saying that our system 
its detrimental for several reasons, ownership its only one of them. So I 
think its fair to question that point (where he got the land from), given 
that its not explained in the video where the land he owns comes from.  I 
suspect, from the story he tells, that its a family house: his family owned 
the land and passed it on to him. But he still owns it. And many people on 
earth don´t even have food to put in their mouths or a blanket to cover 
themselves on, let alone own some land. So life its not easy if you were 
born in the streets without shelter and any food, lacking education (formal 
or non formal) and having nutritional deficiencies while you grow up, which 
will condition you for the rest of your life, leaving your judgment 
impaired because your brain did not develop properly. He never mentions 
that some people dont have the cognitive tools to make a decision like he 
makes, deep insights like his are not natural, they should be nurtured by 
growing in a healthy enviroment, like he said he had when he was growing up 
(away from dangers of the cities, addictions, stress, abnormal ideology of 
esthethics). Being poor in a city will condition your behaviour to a great 
extent, as far as where you can´t see that you don´t really need your job 
or your money, not because you dont want to, but because you never 
experienced anything else. So, how can you go back to your country house if 
you never had one and dont know what they are about? See, not everyone is 
happy planting food and building houses, even if its as easy as he says. 
Now, im not saying that what he is doing is neither right or wrong: it 
seems to me that the life he leads is healthier than mosts. for him and the 
enviroment, but that doesn´t mean that everyone would be happy doing what 
he does. Questioning everything, even something you think its cool like 
this TEDtalk, its part of a healthy and curious mind, as well as an 
important part of the scientific method.
 As you said, laws are made by human, but their are made nonetheless, how 
and why its not for me to say, I dont think Im prepared to answer that 
question, but its probably rooted in the early begginings of ancient 
settlements and agriculture. Is it bad? Is it good? I don´t know, its 
relative, that is why in science they dont speak of bad or good. I myself 
don´t think laws serve their purpose, but what Martin is saying its true: 
life its not easy for everyone, if dont have a land: where you build your 
house? Where you plant your rice? I dont recall the part on the video where 
he says he ´´took´´ the land, its most probable he owns it. As a matter of 
fact, he admitted to sell his surpluss of veggies, which he planted in 
land....which he owned. Because today, owning its the only way of having 
land. Also I dont recall reading anything saying you cant take land. You 
probably can, but then the state will come and ask for your papers, and 
kick you out if you don´t have them. Remember, its a 15 minute video on 
youtube, do your best at questioning the shit out of it.
comments.author: Elian Charif

comments.text:
+Herman Pienaar You probably do not know any people from the country who

if we made a law that would say that anybody can enter anybody's land and

comments.text:
This brings to mind many times where I have asked myself, and my 
co-workers, 'what is the advantage of our life as opposed to those of 
Native Americans'... One could argue that we live longer, and to that I 
would say, 'we toil away all of those extra hours and days'... Another 
argument could be that we have more technology, and are capable of 
accomplishing more, but I have to ask if that makes us happier as a society.

There have been studies done on depression. It is quite an epidemic in 
modernized Western culture. Depression is, however, almost unheard of in 
the native cultures that exist today. They are connected to their work, and 
they are empowered in their own lives to live in a way that is suitable to 
them. In our culture, the idea that we need more or that we aren't good 
enough is continually reinforced through the media, and through 
advertising. Corporations profit off of your fears, anxiety, and 
discomfort, and they are quite effective at creating those conditions.

I suppose the true point that I am trying to make is to ask, are we happy? 
I should take that a step further and ask, are we happier than we were 
before the industrial age? A very compelling case can be made to illustrate 
the sad answer to these questions. The answer is a resounding 'no', and it 
is quite evident through statistical analysis, and mounds of anecdotal 
evidence.

I am not saying that technology should be abandoned. Or that modern society 
should be abandoned. I am saying that at this point in time, I think it is 
pertinent that humanity change its mindset toward utilizing technology to 
increase happiness. People have been mislead to believe that amassing 
copious wealth will bring them happiness, however we are all very well 
aware that this is not the case! So we should focus on what will, because 
this rat race way of life should be left to rats. Sometimes I feel like a 
worker ant droning through the day. We shouldn't live like this. Technology 
should be bringing us past this.﻿

comments.author: MomoTheBellyDancer

comments.text:
This is a truly beautiful sentiment. Life can be hard and it would be 
desirable to make things much less complicated. 

I would like a life like you describe – only working two months a year and 
having a much less complicated life. But before I follow your advice, I’d 
like to ask you a few questions.  Do those houses you built have running 
water? I mean, can you take a hot shower in the morning?  How about indoor 
plumbing.  I’d love to live an easy, uncomplicated life, but I’d hate to 
have to use an outhouse, plus you’d probably have to spend a lot of time 
schlepping human waste to some kind of dumping ground – either that or keep 
digging new holes to bury your poop. I don’t think I’d like to do that much 
digging.  If you don’t have running water, how do you wash your dishes or 
your clothes? Do you have to go down to some river and wash them on a rock? 
I appreciate the fact that you only have one outfit, but you have to wash 
it sometimes, right? Otherwise you must smell like hell. If you don’t have 
indoor plumbing, you have to get your water from somewhere? Do you have a 
well or do you have to carry it from somewhere. Do you have electricity in 
your houses? How about heat or air conditioning? Do you ever get to watch 
television? If not, what is your form of entertainment in the evening? I 
think I like what you said about getting sick – that is, you treat your 
sickness with water and earth. Plus it is a reminder that you’ve done 
something wrong or unhealthy. But I have to wonder what happens when you 
have an abscessed tooth, or your child wakes up with a painful ear 
infection. What do you do then, just rub a little dirt on it? 

Yes, I would like to make my life simpler and less complicated, but I’m 
thinking that your suggestions would not make life easier. Indeed, it 
sounds like a lot of hard work that has to be done everyday to do the 
things that are practically done automatically for people living in modern 
civilization. I’m sure that after a couple of months of living like a 
hermit, most people would gladly accept a few complications in their life 
in exchange for the modern amenities that we in the civilized world take 
for granted. In fact, in reading your bio, I see that you, and I quote: “ … 
continually strives to find easier ways for people to fulfill their basic 
needs.” Continually striving sounds like the opposite of what you’re 
suggesting for the rest of us. ﻿

I think he takes it to an extreme of self-sufficiency. And it is a bit 
dishonest. He relies upon other people to pay for roads and the internet to 
exist. For the clothes he wears even if given to him. By somebody else who 
eventually had to get or wanted to get Something that they could Not make 
all by their individualistic, narcissistic selves. Something that required 
society to exist in order for humans to engage in Socialized Labor for the 
production of something Greater than they could make in Self-sufficient 
isolation.

However, if instead he had made a more reasonable exhortation of Be Happy 
Through Living Within Your Means, then I wouldn't have had to bitch slap 
him for his Robinson Crusoe (a man alone on an island) or Swiss Family 
Robinson, (a family self-sufficient), utopian bullshit.

comments.author: Robert Weekes

comments.text:
To me, the essence of what Jon is saying is not that we should all leave 
our professions and move to farms where we do subsistence farming to 
survive; rather, we all have the option of living a simple and easy life - 
the secret is to be content with what we have and not get caught up in the 
web of mindless materialism.

Of course, there are certain things we cannot change, like the high cost of 
housing, food and medical care, but there are things that we can cut back 
spending on, such as gadgets, branded clothing, expensive cars, etc. More 
often than not we purchase these items not for our own enjoyment, but to 
'keep up' with everybody else.﻿

comments.text:
You may have missed the point of TEDtalks. The idea is to see another 
perspective and take from it what you will. Of course, not everyone can 
live in this manner. Progress on many fronts would come to a screeching 
halt. We have gone from being less specific in our abilities to becoming 
masters of abilities and disciplines. 

What I take away from this is to know yourself and know what you need, not 
what others tell you that you need. If you become more self dependent, then 
your well being and happiness is not contingent on others as much. One 
thing that we have forgotten how to do thanks to a lot of things, but 
especially in the western world, is to be well.

I do not think that just because something is hard that it is not worth 
doing. Accomplishing difficult things is the nature of our intellectual 
being. If we are constantly killing ourselves though, we cannot ensure we 
will be available to conquer these ever important difficult things. 

With all of the distractions of the modern world and the ability to fulfill 
nearly and desire when it rears it's head, it's becoming increasingly 
difficult to know exactly who you are. We're constantly connected, making 
us more and more afraid of being alone, yet we are lonelier than ever. 
Something has to change, and I'm not saying to throw the baby out with the 
bathwater, but instead to dig deep and think long and hard about what we 
need, both as individuals and as a civilization, to push us forward on the 
right path.

We must work together to make the human race a well tuned machine of happy 
and well individuals. When you don't feel well, you seek ways to feel well. 
The human race is no longer a bunch of groups of villages and families. 
It's a complex organization of organisms, when we can realize this we will 
rocket ourselves through progress like nothing we can imagine. We need to 
realize this soon. Otherwise, we are in trouble.

Wow, I can relate very well to what he says. Everything is complicated and 
hard, because we make it that way. The pressure to perform is so high on 
young people, many collapse beneath it. And even after your education, you 
are in a constant need to perform. You see so many people with burnout, it 
is frightening.

But then on the other hand, why do we choose everything to be so hard? 
Isn't it because we want to do something meaningful with our lives? Because 
we want to "advance" the human race? To provide to the greater good for 
humanity to become better?

I personally think I could not stand living like that. In his way. I would 
feel so insignificant, I want to do something with my life. I want to add 
something to society. I believe that one day there will be an "easy" life 
for everyone. We don't have much of a choice, do we?﻿

comments.text:
Жизнь очень простая! Почему мы постоянно ее усложняем?

Предлагаю вам посмотреть потрясающее выступление жителя Таиланда Jon Jandai 
на конференции TEDx. Он говорит только об одном — жизнь простая, а мы сами 
ее постоянно усложняем.

История его такова… Он жил в маленькой тайской деревушке и был счастлив — 
масса свободного времени, фестивали каждую неделю, скромная, но питательная 
еда вдоволь, все жили в своих домах и ели то, что выращивали сами. Затем у 
них в деревне появился телевизор и они стали смотреть передачи, которые 
траслировались из Бангкока. Он резко почувствовал себя несчастным — 
красивые люди и товары, которые теперь ему хотелось достичь. Он отправился 
в Бангкок и много там работал — позволить себе они не мог ничего кроме риса 
и лапши и падтая по выходным, он спал в комнатушке с несколькими людьми и 
был по-настоящему несчастен. В голове Jon зародились сомнения — почему люди 
работают 30 лет чтобы иметь дом, почему должны работать так, что не 
остается времени понять себя и решить счастлив ты или нет?

Он вернулся в деревню и стал жить там. Он говорит, что смог построить дом 
за три месяца и у него осталось 29 лет и 9 месяцев на то, чтобы просто 
лежать и читать книгу.

Он построил еще несколько домов и теперь имел выбор в котором ему жить 
сегодня :) Его друг, которого он называет более умным в школе, работающий 
теперь юристом, работает 30 лет в Бангкоке чтобы выплатить свой дом — у 
нашего героя их уже несколько. «Даже убогая монашка,» — говорит Jon — 
«может построить свой дом и делает это!» Потом он завел огород и тратил на 
него 15 минут в день. У него росло 30 видов овощей и он кормил этим семью, 
а потом начал продавать. То же с одеждой, то же с медициной.

Так почему нам так сложно жить, если так все просто? Что вы думаете про 
это?﻿

comments.text:
Can you say something about what you find of value in this man's message? I 
can't tell whether he's advocating for self-sufficiency in villages, or 
urban exodus, or cobb construction (which, by the way, I've tried, and it's 
incredibly hard to do), or a simple self-knowledge. 

Every right-thinking person would agree that the four basics of food, 
clothing, shelter and healthcare should be available to everyone, but the 
speaker seems to think we can provide those for the world's population by 
rolling back civilization and technology. 

We could all benefit *enormously* from simplifying our minds and our lives, 
choosing easy over hard, questioning our ridiculous 30 year mortgages and 
the wage-slavery they reduce us to. That's a pretty good message. But about 
six billion of us would have to die so that the happy remaining billion 
could go back to the Garden and live in primitive bliss.

*Life is easy. Why do we make it so hard?*

Here's a crazy person. His name is Jon Jandai and he's from Thailand. He's 
brilliant. He doesn't need universities, banks, mortgages, loans, latest 
fashion clothing to be happy. He comes from the country where it used to be 
a norm to work two months a year, and spend the rest getting to know 
yourself.

He is right. We made this world uncivilized. Food, house, clothing, 
medicine: this should be cheap and easy, but it's not. All living rats in 
the world can dig a hole in one night, and make themselves a house. All 
living birds can make a nest in two days, and make themselves a house. Most 
humans can make themselves a house in thirty years.

What are we doing wrong? We succumbed to clever marketing. We traded our 
happiness for stuff.

Here's to the crazy ones!

comments.text:
An excellent talk by Jon Jandai from Thailand about how life doesn't have to be complex - Story of a guy who simplified his life & found his own success! - Thanks to +Visnja Zeljeznjakand +David Kasiniak   for sharing this. (Video below)

Part summary below:
- He moved to the big city and tried to follow success but found the harder he chased success the more complicated and harder life seemed to be.
- He thought back to when he was a kid. No one worked 8 hours a day all year round but they only worked for 2 months of the year, sow rice for the 1st month and harvest the rice the 2nd month. The rest of the time was free time.
- That's why they have so many festivals in Thailand! Free time. Everyone even took a nap during the day and when they woke, they had time to catch up with friends & family and have the time to spend together.
- They had the time to enjoy the beauty in life. That's why they express that beauty via many creative ways. Some make beautiful carvings, others create beautiful things made by hand.

After much thought Jon decided to quit working so hard chasing this current ideal of success and went back home.
- He went home to live the life he remembered as a child, simple and easy.
- He started to work 2 months per year.
- He produced 4 tons of rice more than enough for his whole family of 6 who ate less than half a ton per year. The rest he could sell.
- He dug up 2 fish ponds which gave them fish to eat all year long.
- He started a garden and spends 15 min per day to take care of it. The garden has more than 30 varieties in it more than enough to feed the whole family. The surplus they sell to make an extra income.

So to him life was easy
- He says, why go to a big city for many years and work very hard and then don't have enough to eat?
- Here now, with only 2 months work and 15 min a day in the garden and they all have more than enough food for 6 people and lots of free time to enjoy life!
- Jon wondered how can he have a house because the common conception was that you have to be successful to own a house. He didn't even finish university!
- He learned how to do some Earth building (Mud bricks).
- Spent 2 hours a day for 3 months and he had a house!
- A clever friend of his that was at the top of his class also spent 3
months getting his house built for him, but now he is in debt for the next 30 years!
- Jon builds a house every year, now he has many homes!
- He said, birds can lay a nest in a few days. A rat can dig a hole in a night.
But clever humans like us spend 30 years to have a home to live in.

He said something was wrong or abnormal with society. We're some how uncivilised rather than civilised. - Interesting thoughts.
comments.author: Nobilangelo Ceramalus

- They had the time to enjoy the beauty in life. That's why they express that beauty via many creative ways. Some make beautiful carvings, others create beautiful things made by hand.

After much thought Jon decided to quit working so hard chasing this current ideal of success and went back home.
- He went home to live the life he remembered as a child, simple and easy.

- He produced 4 tons of rice more than enough for his whole family of 6 who ate less than half a ton per year. The rest he could sell.

So to him life was easy
- He says, why go to a big city for many years and work very hard and then don't have enough to eat?
- Here now, with only 2 months work and 15 min a day in the garden and they all have more than enough food for 6 people and lots of free time to enjoy life!
- Jon wondered how can he have a house because the common conception was that you have to be successful to own a house. He didn't even finish university!

But clever humans like us spend 30 years to have a home to live in.

comments.text:
Yeah I love this video +Visnja Zeljeznjak, that's why I put the time in to 
taking notes and writing it up. I was going to post this a few days ago but 
really wanted some quality time where I could do it. There are key 
fundamental principals here and I really hope people that come across it 
can see them.

The way we are conditioned and hard wired I think is wrong. I think that 
much of our misery comes from having our minds set in a specific mold much 
like 90%+ of the masses. We link our happiness to physical things but the 
result is that you have to constantly chase things to fill that empty void. 
I think that our happiness and contentment is already within us. It's our 
thinking that needs to change in order to bring happiness and contentment. 
We need to not complicate things so much. Like Jon said in the video, there 
are 4 things we need: Food, house, clothes and medicine (health). Pretty 
simple. He also said that some people think he's crazy but he said that he 
can not control what people think or do on the outside so he doesn't worry 
about it, he can only control what he thinks, so he is happy anyway!

+Visnja Zeljeznjak I love lamps too, I like the ambience they create. I 
have one on now next to my laptop. After having a number of toys, I realize 
you only need a few essentials, laptop and phone a few of them!
comments.author: David Kasiniak

comments.text: +William Matsushima you have most interesting profile :)
comments.author: Visnja Zeljeznjak (luckyisgood)

comments.text:
I'm so glad people love this video. This video made the most impact of all 
stuff I've seen online for at least one year. I think about Jandai and what 
he said every day. Luckily it's easy for me to untether from most stuff, 
because I don't own almost anything (and prefer it that way). My company 
owns the laptop and the smartphone I don't want to be without (luckily I 
co-own that company so it's not like anybody could take those two things 
from me). The rest, I only borrow and dispose of when it breaks.

Ok I do own one reading lamp. I like it because it lightens up my evenings 
and shines light on all the wonderful knowledge I want to acquire.

I don't think it's that hard to live life as simple as Jandai describes. 
It's easy, actually. There's cheap land all over the place (at least in 
Croatia). What is hard, is to untether from this existence we all live now, 
to make the decision to break away from it, to become a crazy weirdo 
everyone makes fun of (but everyone is secretly envious of).
comments.author: Visnja Zeljeznjak (luckyisgood)

comments.text:
+David Kasiniak let's carry water and chop wood. ;-) 

Great post. We long for simplicity. Form is not important. The ego makes

While we are here we need to heal the wrong mind. Just carry on chopping 
wood and carry water.
comments.author: Johan Horak

comments.text:
+Shintaro Tominaga Oh sorry I mean Bill ; ) I do realize that it's not that 
easy for us all to just drop everything and move to a village and start 
growing things and being totally self sufficient like the example here. But 
the value with this video is in the idea or the concept that we are prone 
to getting too carried away and working hard like slaves for what? Do we 
really need what we are working for and are we getting these things via the 
correct motivations? Eg. According to our inner values or is it ego driven.
My friend +Johan Horak and I have had a few discussions along these lines 
and how the illusion of ego can distract you from what you really need in 
life. Glad you liked the video +Shintaro Tominaga - Some good ideas there!
comments.author: David Kasiniak

comments.text:
+alm Lazaro Thank you for your wonderful comments! This is a great video 
and I also agree with the fellow in the video, my thinking is similar. 
There are too many complexities and distractions in life that take people 
away from true happiness. Most of us are too busy working to realize that 
we are missing out on the real valuable things in life.

For example along the lines of what Jon in the video said, he doesn't worry 
too much about fashion. I have friends that are always keeping up with the 
latest fashion and even buying really expensive cloths like $500 pair of 
jeans and things like that. Then they borrow big money to buy expensive 
cars. *But guess what? They never have any money and have to work all day 
every day for this and even miss out on time with friends and loved 
ones........for what? A pair of jeans that you could get for $50? A car you 
could get at a reasonable price?*

People need to think - Is what they do really worth it? And are they 
following the right ideals and the right values? I think there are some 
great lessons in this video. +Visnja Zeljeznjak finds great stuff to share!

But (why is there always a but?)... I was exploring satisfaction in my

our expactations. They manage us. :)

comments.text:
+Dusan Vrban - I understand what you are saying when you say we cant all 
just drop what we are doing, move to Thailand and work on a farm 2 months 
of the year and do what the fellow in the video is doing.

But it's the concept or idea that we don't have to "over complicate" life 
as in getting in to excessive debt to buy things that we don't need and so 
on which I find of value in the video. Many people are enslaved by their 
belongings and their ideals of success and by having the wrong mindset they 
are really moving away from what they really want in life.

By all means it's great if people enjoy technology and the lifestyle they 
live and for many it's worth the hard work. The problem comes when some 
over complicate their lives by chasing a false idea of success or chasing 
goods that they think they need when all that is happening is they become 
more enslaved to the system. I liked some of the concepts that were 
discussed in the video but I'm not moving to a farm on Thailand anytime 
soon. ; )

comments.text:
While *I agree* with many things here, I would like to express that in my 
opinion *truth is somewhere in between*. Because if we only worked for 2 
months a year, nobody would be reading this post today. Because internet 
would not exist. :) And now you can say you're ok with it, but you're not. 
:)

On the other hand, I am a strong advocate of working less. In our company, 
we work 6 hours on *average*. And even that is much, we should all be 
working around 4 hours at top.

But while it can be easy for many of us to make this change, doing it 
globally is what will take place eventually. We just have to belive it.

There is also another important thing we must know - bird can make a nest 
in 2 days, but it can vanish in first bad weather. Bird is wet and cold in 
that nest. I feel good when it is raining outside because it is warm in my 
appartment.

I don't need new branded jeans or something to make me look as a star. But 
I do need culture, love, technology, ideas, research. I want that humanity 
learns more about space, travel. I can't accept total simplicity.
comments.author: Dusan Vrban

comments.text:
I completely agree with you +Visnja Zeljeznjak. We are a society that is 
constantly being brain washed and conditioned to act and to react to the 
stimulus they feed us on a constant basis. We think we are free but we are 
really enslaved to this system. Schools are only allowed to teach what is 
part of a curriculum set forth by the government. You see +Visnja Zeljeznjak, 
school is really a factory that produces tax payers, it is not designed to 
teach you real life lessons or how to make money work for you but rather 
you work for money, pay bills to the big companies, taxes to the 
government, loans to the banks and have only a few crumbs left for yourself 
and your family.

Some of the richest people in the world were school drop outs where many of 
the ones that did well in school have ended up working for the companies 
owned by the drop outs. The school drop outs like Gates or Richard Branson 
or Zuckerberg by passed the system and broke the rules which put them above 
all the rest.

We live in a weird world. Our perceptions of reality are warped by the news 
and media which are controlled by certain powers with vested interests 
which lay behind the scenes and behind the governments. Advertising is 
another form of manipulation out there through the media. You are 
right......it's poison and people do not realize it. Much of this 
conditioning destroys our creativity and full potential.
comments.author: David Kasiniak

comments.text:
I remember that post of yours, +David Kasiniak, it made an impact on me 
too. 

The best way to untether from the reality, and I really believe this is 
what we need to do to start being more free, is to stop pouring poison into 
our minds. Poison is everyday news. It's like people walking with dirty 
feet inside our minds. You'd never believe how much bullshit you start 
seeing around once you untether from news and media, until you try being 
without it for at least a few months. You never want to go back.
comments.author: Visnja Zeljeznjak (luckyisgood)

comments.text:
Oh yeah I watched the whole thing from the beginning to the end +Visnja 
Zeljeznjak don't worry about that! It was awesome! Many excellent points to 
be taken from it! I was going to write up a post last night but I was out 
all day and was tired when I go home so I left it for the morning (now), 
feeling refreshed. I have learned to only post when your feeling sharp 
other wise you will write up a post while tired then the next day look at 
it and think, 'that was crap!'!

But anyway the video above points out that life doesn't have to be so 
complicated or hard. His people work to get lots of food only a few months 
of the year and the rest they get time to think, spend time with family 
etc. Here in the western world people work like slaves and most people get 
them selves in to huge debt and pay off mortgages over 30 years. This 
society and the system we live in is part of the problem. I mentioned in 
that post I wrote with the moving image with rain falling on a plant, that 
nature gets all it needs easily and effortlessly for free, while we have to 
struggle in a complex world. Something is wrong with the system

TEDxDoiSuthep - Jon Jandai - Life is easy. Why do we make it so hard?

Jon is a farmer from northeastern Thailand. He founded the Pun Pun Center 
for Self-reliance, an organic farm outside Chiang Mai, with his wife Peggy 
Reents in 2003. Pun Pun doubles as a center for sustainable living and seed 
production, aiming to bring indigenous and rare seeds back into use. It 
regularly hosts training on simple techniques to live more sustainably. 
Outside of Pun Pun, Jon is a leader in bringing the natural building 
movement to Thailand, appearing as a spokesperson on dozens of publications 
and TV programs for the past 10 years. He continually strives to find 
easier ways for people to fulfill their basic needs. For more information 
visit﻿

comments.text:
Thank you +Goins Girl for this suggestion. This man speaks truth, please 
watch. 

I have been somewhat miserable lately. I'm always thinking of how corrupt 
everything is and how impossible is it to defeat the greedy bastards. But a 
small flicker of joy has recently sparked in me when I realized that we can 
build our own homes and completely sustain ourselves off of our own 
gardens. 

I think this simple lifestyle is our future. The 200 year experiment in 
cheap-energy is coming to an end. The era of everything-all-the-time is 
over. We will soon find ourselves getting back to the basics, and I think 
we will be a happier society for it. 

Next step for me: researching states or English speaking counties that have 
no property tax.﻿

comments.text:
The message in this video speaks to the madness of chasing the dollar - and 
I admire the speaker for knowing himself well enough to NOT buy in to it. I 
also have been simplifying my life - walking away from a Corporate career, 
living away from the masses on our 5-acre haven, starting a small garden, 
becoming debt-free, etc., but have yet to achieve the complete 
self-reliance I so desire. For 3 years we have toyed with the idea of 
selling this house and using the equity to pay cash to build an "Earth 
home" with a solar or wind-powered energy system, so we truly may live "off 
the grid". This video may be the spark that finally ignites that fire -- 
thank you for sharing!
